{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3525669,"name":"Krithik Alluri","username":"Krithik2720","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/b9bd4f/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-02-13T03:30:15.517Z","cooked":"

Hi Everyone,

We are currently trying to spin an arm on our robot, and no matter what we do, we can only get our arm to spin clockwise. We found no mechanical or electrical problems, only that when setting one motor as a follower in REV hardware and running both motors, our arm only spins in one direction. We also tried running our arm from code and it only runs clockwise from there as well.

Link to our code: https://github.com/2729StormRobotics/RedWatch2025/tree/main2/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/arm

Screenshot 2025-02-12 at 10.16.35 PM591×597 115 KB

image563×693 80.7 KB

image560×541 68.3 KB

Thanks,
Krithik Alluri from 2720

I think your issues relate to the fact that the Spark PID + Absolute encoder has no concept of “negative” values.

It looks like in Armconstants, all your L1/L2/L3 values are 0: Which is a discontinuity, and the Spark PID cannot handle it.

When your arm tries to go to zero, it will go slightly past… resulting in an encoder angle of 359. And so it will act to reduce this to zero… by continuing to go clockwise.

There’s unfortunately no good solution here, owing to limitations in the Rev API. But here’s the general options:

  • Enable the PID Wrapping from 0 to 360. This (effectively) allows the PID act as if 359 is equivalent to -1, and can thus go backwards.
  • Don’t directly PID to the absolute encoder, and instead use the Absolute encoder to set the Spark’s Relative Encoder to the known system angle on boot. Then, PID to the Relative encoder.

The second option is probably the safer one, depending on the system. With PID wrapping and absolute encoders enabled, you functionally cannot use soft limits, and if your system range of motion is over 180 degrees, you need to be very careful about how you tell the motor to get from point A to B or it’ll try to power through itself. With a relative encoder, this is a non-issue.
